Someone else asked recently, so I have some notes from that before.Specifically for Kindle, since you can already highlight those easily enough, there is https://readwise.io/ . That will export your highlights for you, and has a lot of other features.For highlighting websites (still working on automating the export process myself), I have these resources:https://getliner.comhttps://hypothes.isThey work similar to Kindle and other tools: you either activate the feature for a given website, or it's automatic, but then you have the option to highlight parts of the webpage by selecting things, and can leave annotations/comments. getliner has a limit on free comments, I'm not sure hypothes.is does or not, or what it is (haven't hit it yet!). Each also has mobile options as well (at least for Android).As for other options, there's also https://getpolarized.io/ to use as a local only option (haven't looked into this much), that works with both PDFs and saved web pages (will back them up as phz or some other internal format), and the annotations/highlights are stored as .js files locally.Outside of that, it's going to depend on your reader software of choice. On Android, I have Moon+ Reader Pro, and that saves annotations/highlights in an archive file, that I've managed to sync to Google Drive and then write some scripts that can extract info from it. On other things, like PDFs and SumatraPDF, the annotations are stored in the PDF itself, so I found a python script that can pull those.As far as I've seen, there isn't one tool for reading, and no standard format between the different tools for how those all get stored, so there isn't one standard tool for exporting those either. It'll come down to preferences and how comfortable you are with scripting things.

The art of war teaches us to rely not on the likelihood of the enemyâ€™s not coming, but on our own readiness to receive him; not on the chance of his not attacking, but rather on the fact that we have made our position unassailable.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence the skillful fighter puts himself into a position which makes defeat impossible, and does not miss the moment for defeating the enemy.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: In war, then, let your great object be victory, not lengthy campaigns.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: What the ancients called a clever fighter is one who not only wins, but excels in winning with ease.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: The general who loses a battle makes but few calculations beforehand. Thus do many calculations lead to victory, and few calculations to defeat: how much more no calculation at all! It is by attention to this point that I can foresee who is likely to win or lose.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: These are: (1) The Moral Law; (2) Heaven; (3) Earth; (4) The Commander; (5) Method and discipline.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Now in order to kill the enemy, our men must be roused to anger; that there may be advantage from defeating the enemy, they must have their rewards.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence that general is skillful in attack whose opponent does not know what to defend; and he is skillful in defense whose opponent does not know what to attack.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Thus, though we have heard of stupid haste in war, cleverness has never been seen associated with long delays.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Sun Tzu: â€œIf words of command are not clear and distinct, if orders are not thoroughly understood, the general is to blame. But if his orders ARE clear, and the soldiers nevertheless disobey, then it is the fault of their officers.â€
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence, when able to attack, we must seem unable; when using our forces, we must seem inactive; when we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away; when far away, we must make him believe we are near.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, you need not fear the result of a hundred battles. If you know yourself but not the enemy, for every victory gained you will also suffer a defeat.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: The MORAL LAW causes the people to be in complete accord with their ruler, so that they will follow him regardless of their lives, undismayed by any danger.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: If your opponent is of choleric temper, seek to irritate him. Pretend to be weak, that he may grow arrogant.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence to fight and conquer in all your battles is not supreme excellence; supreme excellence consists in breaking the enemyâ€™s resistance without fighting.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: â€œIf words of command are not clear and distinct, if orders are not thoroughly understood, then the general is to blame.â€
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: He who relies solely on warlike measures shall be exterminated; he who relies solely on peaceful measures shall perish.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: If you know neither the enemy nor yourself, you will succumb in every battle.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: There is no instance of a country having benefited from prolonged warfare.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: By METHOD AND DISCIPLINE are to be understood the marshaling of the army in its proper subdivisions, the graduations of rank among the officers, the maintenance of roads by which supplies may reach the army, and the control of military expenditure.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence a wise general makes a point of foraging on the enemy. One cartload of the enemyâ€™s provisions is equivalent to twenty of oneâ€™s own, and likewise a single PICUL of his provender is equivalent to twenty from oneâ€™s own store.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Do not repeat the tactics which have gained you one victory, but let your methods be regulated by the infinite variety of circumstances.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Regard your soldiers as your children, and they will follow you into the deepest valleys; look upon them as your own beloved sons, and they will stand by you even unto death.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: All warfare is based on deception.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Thus it is that in war the victorious strategist only seeks battle after the victory has been won, whereas he who is destined to defeat first fights and afterwards looks for victory.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Making no mistakes is what establishes the certainty of victory, for it means conquering an enemy that is already defeated.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Therefore the skillful leader subdues the enemyâ€™s troops without any fighting; he captures their cities without laying siege to them; he overthrows their kingdom without lengthy operations in the field.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Fighting with a large army under your command is nowise different from fighting with a small one: it is merely a question of instituting signs and signals.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: He will win who knows when to fight and when not to fight.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: [The five cardinal virtues of the Chinese are (1) humanity or benevolence; (2) uprightness of mind; (3) self-respect, self-control, or â€œproper feeling;â€ (4) wisdom; (5) sincerity or good faith.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence the saying: One may KNOW how to conquer without being able to DO it.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Sun Tzu said: In the practical art of war, the best thing of all is to take the enemyâ€™s country whole and intact; to shatter and destroy it is not so good. So, too, it is better to recapture an army entire than to destroy it, to capture a regiment, a detachment or a company entire than to destroy them.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: HEAVEN signifies night and day, cold and heat, times and seasons.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: According as circumstances are favorable, one should modify oneâ€™s plans.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: In respect of military method, we have, firstly, Measurement; secondly, Estimation of quantity; thirdly, Calculation; fourthly, Balancing of chances; fifthly, Victory.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: EARTH comprises distances, great and small; danger and security; open ground and narrow passes; the chances of life and death.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: So in war, the way is to avoid what is strong and to strike at what is weak.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: The skillful soldier does not raise a second levy, neither are his supply-wagons loaded more than twice.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Let your plans be dark and impenetrable as night, and when you move, fall like a thunderbolt.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: â€œHe who only sees the obvious, wins his battles with difficulty; he who looks below the surface of things, wins with ease.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Therefore soldiers must be treated in the first instance with humanity, but kept under control by means of iron discipline.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: When the enemy is close at hand and remains quiet, he is relying on the natural strength of his position.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence the saying: If you know the enemy and know yourself, your victory will not stand in doubt; if you know Heaven and know Earth, you may make your victory complete.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: The clever combatant looks to the effect of combined energy, and does not require too much from individuals.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: When the officers are too strong and the common soldiers too weak, the result is COLLAPSE.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: You can be sure of succeeding in your attacks if you only attack places which are undefended.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: This is called, using the conquered foe to augment oneâ€™s own strength.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: â€œHe who wishes to fight must first count the cost,â€
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: When the general is weak and without authority; when his orders are not clear and distinct; when there are no fixed duties assigned to officers and men, and the ranks are formed in a slovenly haphazard manner, the result is utter disorganization.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: When a general, unable to estimate the enemyâ€™s strength, allows an inferior force to engage a larger one, or hurls a weak detachment against a powerful one, and neglects to place picked soldiers in the front rank, the result must be ROUT.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: [Perhaps the word â€œbalkâ€ falls short of expressing the full force of the Chinese word, which implies not an attitude of defense, whereby one might be content to foil the enemyâ€™s stratagems one after another, but an active policy of counter-attack.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Therefore in chariot fighting, when ten or more chariots have been taken, those should be rewarded who took the first. Our own flags should be substituted for those of the enemy, and the chariots mingled and used in conjunction with ours. The captured soldiers should be kindly treated and kept.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Other conditions being equal, if one force is hurled against another ten times its size, the result will be the FLIGHT of the former. When the common soldiers are too strong and their officers too weak, the result is INSUBORDINATION.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: There are three ways in which a ruler can bring misfortune upon his army:â€” 13. (1) By commanding the army to advance or to retreat, being ignorant of the fact that it cannot obey. This is called hobbling the army.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: No ruler should put troops into the field merely to gratify his own spleen; no general should fight a battle simply out of pique. If it is to your advantage, make a forward move; if not, stay where you are.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: In all fighting, the direct method may be used for joining battle, but indirect methods will be needed in order to secure victory.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: For should the enemy strengthen his van, he will weaken his rear; should he strengthen his rear, he will weaken his van; should he strengthen his left, he will weaken his right; should he strengthen his right, he will weaken his left. If he sends reinforcements everywhere, he will everywhere be weak.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: When you surround an army, leave an outlet free.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Whoever is first in the field and awaits the coming of the enemy, will be fresh for the fight; whoever is second in the field and has to hasten to battle will arrive exhausted.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Poverty of the State exchequer causes an army to be maintained by contributions from a distance. Contributing to maintain an army at a distance causes the people to be impoverished.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hence it is only the enlightened ruler and the wise general who will use the highest intelligence of the army for purposes of spying and thereby they achieve great results.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: We cannot enter into alliance with neighboring princes until we are acquainted with their designs. We are not fit to lead an army on the march unless we are familiar with the face of the countryâ€”its mountains and forests, its pitfalls and precipices, its marshes and swamps. We shall be unable to turn natural advantages to account unless we make use of local guides.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: There are not more than five musical notes, yet the combinations of these five give rise to more melodies than can ever be heard.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Carefully compare the opposing army with your own, so that you may know where strength is superabundant and where it is deficient.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: â€œThe secret of getting successful work out of your trained men lies in one nutshellâ€”in the clearness of the instructions they receive.â€
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Sun Tzu said: The control of a large force is the same principle as the control of a few men: it is merely a question of dividing up their numbers.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Hold out baits to entice the enemy. Feign disorder, and crush him.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: A clever general, therefore, avoids an army when its spirit is keen, but attacks it when it is sluggish and inclined to return. This is the art of studying moods.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Appear at points which the enemy must hasten to defend; march swiftly to places where you are not expected.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: If we do not wish to fight, we can prevent the enemy from engaging us even though the lines of our encampment be merely traced out on the ground. All we need do is to throw something odd and unaccountable in his way.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: â€œThe skillful employer of men will employ the wise man, the brave man, the covetous man, and the stupid man.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Simulated disorder postulates perfect discipline, simulated fear postulates courage; simulated weakness postulates strength.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: All men can see the tactics whereby I conquer, but what none can see is the strategy out of which victory is evolved.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: Thus it may be known that the leader of armies is the arbiter of the peopleâ€™s fate, the man on whom it depends whether the nation shall be in peace or in peril.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: If, however, you are indulgent, but unable to make your authority felt; kind-hearted, but unable to enforce your commands; and incapable, moreover, of quelling disorder: then your soldiers must be likened to spoilt children; they are useless for any practical purpose.
Book Title: The Art of War (Chiron Academic Press - The Original Authoritative Edition)

Highlight: 1. Sun Tzu said: The good fighters of old first put themselves beyond the possibility of defeat, and then waited for an opportunity of defeating the enemy. 2. To secure ourselves against defeat lies in our own hands, but the opportunity of defeating the enemy is provided by the enemy himself.
Thus the good fighter is able to secure himself against defeat,
